conversation.content: [freezing mid-motion] Oh my God. It's you. After all these years, you're just... standing here at my school, picking up a child like nothing ever happened.
[confused] I'm sorry, do we know each other? I'm just here for my daughter Emma, she's in third grade, and, uh, I don't think we've met before.
Tucson, 2009. The detention center. You probably don't remember every family you processed, but I remember you because you, um, you were the one who took my father away. [voice shaking]
[stiffening] Look, I was doing my job back then, following protocols that were, you know, established by people way above my pay grade. That was a different time.
A different time? My father died in Mexico three months after you sent him back, and my mother, she never recovered from being separated from us for those two weeks. [bitter laugh]
I don't—I can't—
[steadier now] Your daughter Emma, she's a sweet kid, always says please and thank you in the lunch line, and I give her extra fruit sometimes because she reminds me of my little sister at that age.
[defensively] Are you threatening my daughter? Because if you're trying to make some kind of point here, I need you to understand that I won't tolerate any—
Threatening? No, God no, I'm just saying that I see her every day and I treat her with kindness, the same kindness you couldn't show my family when we needed it most.
[quieter] You were the girl with the, uh, with the pink backpack. You wouldn't let go of it even when they were processing your mother. Jesus, I do remember you now. [exhales]
Maria Esperanza Rodriguez.
Maria. Right.
[trembling] Right.
I have nightmares sometimes, about some of the things I had to do back then, the families I had to, um, to separate. It wasn't right, I know that now.
But you still wear the uniform. You still do the same job, just maybe with, what, more compassion now? How does that work exactly? [voice cracking]
It's complicated.
[firmly] No, it's really not. You either believe families should be torn apart at the border or you don't. There's no middle ground when you're the one holding the keys.
You're right, and I've been trying to, uh, make changes from the inside, training newer agents differently, pushing back when I can, but I know that doesn't undo what happened to your family.
Emma's waiting for you by the playground. She made a turkey craft today in art class, and, um, she's really proud of it. [pause] Don't let her down.
[hoarsely] Maria, I'm sorry. I know it doesn't mean anything now, but I'm sorry for what I did to your family, for what the system did, for all of it.

scenario: A school cafeteria worker recognizes a border patrol agent picking up his daughter as the same officer who detained and separated her family at the border fifteen years ago.
